papers.title: Eunuchs in the Byzantine Empire
papers.abstract: By the term eunuchos, as well as by the terms thladias (a man whose testicles were intentionally crushed), spadon (a eunuch due to natural reasons), and ektomias (a castrated man), which designated different types of eunuchs, the Byzantines identified any male person deprived, fully or in part, of his genitals. This may have occurred in early childhood or at a later age, of his own will, through natural processes, or by the acts of others, and it may have happened for moral, medical, or economic purposes. A eunuch could also be any person who, for natural reasons, a lack of hygiene, or other reasons, had become permanently or temporarily unfit to procreate, or even, in some cases, to sexually perform. These terms also appear in theological contexts to reflect the situation of pre- or post-lapsarian man, as well as to sometimes denote the angels. Therefore, as a concept expressed through many terms, eunuch referred to a variety of cases and people, situations, and behaviors; at the same time, it alluded to the biblical imaginary and the theological symbolism established upon it. However, the secondary literature dedicated to eunuchs has until now mainly focused on the ektomiai, or castrati, and the roles they assumed in Byzantine society. The history of the study of eunuchs in Byzantium closely follows and, in a way, exemplifies the ways in which modern historians have viewed Byzantium itself more generally (i.e., in close relation to the values of their own societies). In general, moving past the strongly orientalist perspective which prevailed in the nineteenth and early twentieth centuries, scholars proceeded to study the role of eunuchs in the administration of state and Church. Eunuchs are treated in these approaches as a separate category of people or as influential individuals who were sometimes even worthy of a biography. In recent years, eunuchs have begun to be treated as sexual beings and a discussion has arisen concerning the question of whether they constituted a third sex or gender or whether they remained within the margins of the sexual dimorphism that was seen as a divinely established ‘reality.’ These approaches, which appeared successively, are now studied in a comprehensive fashion and have given rise to a fairly diversified bibliographical landscape, where the study of the political role of eunuchs coexists with that which focuses on their sexual identity. An openly orientalist (and regressive) approach nevertheless remains present in publications for the general public and in historical novels.

papers.title: Victim and perpetrator accounts of interpersonal conflict: Autobiographical narratives about anger.
papers.abstract: Subjects furnished autobiographical accounts of being angered (victim narratives) and of angering someone else (perpetrator narratives). The provoking behavior was generally portrayed by the perpetrator as meaningful and comprehensible, whereas the victim tended to depict it as arbitrary, gratuitous, or incomprehensible. Victim accounts portrayed the incident in a long-term context that carried lasting implications, especially of continuing harm, loss, and grievance. Perpetrator accounts tended to cast the incident as a closed, isolated incident that did not have lasting implications. Several findings fit a hypothesis that interpersonal conflicts may arise when a victim initially stifles anger and then finally responds to an accumulated series of provocations, whereas the perpetrator perceives only the single incident and regards the angry response as an unjustified overreaction. Victim and perpetrator roles are associated with different subjective interpretations.

papers.title: Moral Traces and Relational Autonomy
papers.abstract: One feature of James Childress's approach to ethics is the experience of "moral traces" that agents ought to feel in situations of conflict after they have overridden one strong value for the sake of another.1 This experience grasps at something intuitive about the moral life, that in situations of intense moral conflict when we are faced with a choice to act in a way that goes against a deeply held value, it is morally important that we feel and respond a certain way. At the most immediate level, this might entail privately mourning or grieving that we had to violate the value. Doing so would affirm that we care about the overridden value, and by acknowledging such a care we would feel that our moral integrity has been protected. But shouldn't the concept of moral traces entail more than a private process of grief? Shouldn't it have an effect on our relations with others? Moral traces ought to obligate us to act toward others in certain ways, and in that sense it is a concept quite distinct from the pangs of conscience we feel when we have behaved badly. At the very least, these traces ought to press us to offer an explanation or justification to others for why we acted against an important moral value, especially if those others were affected negatively by our action. In more extreme cases, we might even be compelled to make amends or offer reparations to the one or ones who were harmed by our action.2In this article I am interested in sorting through the ways that moral traces function in the moral life, especially in terms of the work they do in maintaining and building social and institutional relationships. I want to suggest that moral traces are more than an internal attitude that pertains to individual flourishing; they are also integral to communal well-being. By pointing to a contrast between moral traces as important for individual flourishing and moral traces as conducive to increased communal well-being, I also hope to expand our thinking about the liberal principle of autonomy that is central to Childress's approach. I am motivated in this article by a worry that some might use the appeal to moral traces to reinforce an individualistic, psychological notion of the self. This is clearly something that Childress does not do, as can be seen in his 1970 Soundings article, "Who Shall Live When Not All Can Live?" There he tethers the equitable distribution of scarce medical resources firmly to the maintenance of relationships of trust. In later writings, he explicitly outlines the obligations to others that emerge in situations when an important value has been overridden. Relationships of trust and the obligations to others incurred by moral traces both point to a conception of agency that is relational.In what follows, I hope to suggest the broad contours of an account of moral traces that highlights its relational features. Looking at moral traces through a relational lens accentuates, and perhaps even intensifies, the obligations that they incur. Put differently, relational conceptions of autonomy require a more careful account of moral traces—one that focuses on what we owe one another. By a relational conception of autonomy, I mean a view of agency that sees the choices we make as shaped by our relations with and commitment to others. Highlighting moral traces as central to the moral life is a way to recognize the importance of human accountability, which ensures that we are always fully aware of how our actions affect others. Ultimately, the significance of the effect of moral traces does not lie simply in protecting an agent's integrity or sense of herself as morally whole but rather in how it promotes the building and maintaining of relations.Annette Baier makes this point eloquently in her critique of Michael Stocker's account of moral guilt—a concept that, while not exactly synonymous with moral traces, does share a family resemblance. She notes that although Stocker is concerned about the effects of moral dilemmas, his "attention is given to the emotions of choosers, not to the feelings of the victims or beneficiaries of their choices" (1992, 363). At another point, Baier refers to the "dirty hands" metaphor as pushing us "into a Lady Macbeth frame of mind, obsessed with our own stained character rather than what we have done to others and how that felt for them" (363).3 It is precisely this sense of how those harmed by our actions might feel that makes moral traces such a central component of a relational account of morality. Baier writes, "Without a moral psychology that puts informed empathy and willingness to listen to others' point of view squarely in the center of our moral-psychological capacities, without a social interactive account both of rationality and of morality, the constraints that moral psychology can put on what counts as 'a more acceptable version of ethics' will be merely formal and very limited" (365).While Childress does not use the term moral traces in his early Soundings article, he does offer some brief thoughts that hint at its further development in later writings. His short mention of moral guilt in this article serves as an impetus for my reflections about how moral traces can serve a relationship-building or maintaining purpose. I begin by assessing what he says in the Soundings article, especially as it relates to the view of the theologian Helmut Thielicke, whom Childress discusses in this article. I then look to Childress's discussion of moral traces in later writings on war, bioethics, and public health. Finally, as a way to further examine the relational implications of the concept, I turn to two fairly recent concepts in the bioethics literature: moral distress in nursing ethics and "the patient as victim and vector model" in public health ethics. While certainly not identical to Childress's conception of moral traces, these concepts reinforce a similar sentiment about relationality and our obligations to others in difficult moral cases. They also help us see that moral traces are not only located in the individual conscience or in the moral universe more generally; their effects are also embodied in institutional procedures.4 This echoes Childress's sentiment in the 1970 Soundings article that one of the tasks of social ethics is "to propose relatively just institutional arrangements within which self-interested and biased men can live" (Childress 1970, 342).In the 1970 article "Who Shall Live When Not All Can Live?," James Childress makes a passing reference to a concept that forms a connective tissue through the corpus of his work in areas as diverse as conscience, war, and bioethics. He suggests that the allocation of scarce lifesaving medical resources (SLMR) presents us with "'borderline situations' which inevitably involve guilt" (1970, 175). He borrows the phrase "borderline situations" from the German theologian Helmut Thielicke, who had only recently addressed the issue of allocation of scarce lifesaving resources at a symposium held in Texas. It is not fully clear in his brief discussion of Thielicke whether or not Childress believes that decisions about allocating scarce medical resources must involve guilt.5 He writes, "Even if all actions in SLMR should involve guilt, some may preserve human dignity to a greater extent than others" (347). What is clear, however, is that he distances himself from Thielicke's view that the best humans can do in the face of these borderline situations is "to understand and endure—not 'solve'" them. By contrast, Childress believes that one can make discriminating judgments using the tools of ethics so that even our choices about "who shall live when not all can live" are informed by the notion that some decisions may "preserve human dignity to a greater extent than others." For him the preservation of human dignity is achieved through a careful evaluation of the factors and norms in a given situation. Thus, whereas for Thielicke, any ethical judgment in such situations is flawed, Childress holds more optimistically that reasoned ethical judgments are possible. For both of them, however, the agent's realization that she is affected in some way by such difficult moral choices is important to her human flourishing. What is unclear in this brief reference is the nature and extent of this effect on the moral agent. Does it morally obligate her to make some sort of amends, or does it simply do its work on a psychological level in terms of ensuring that the overridden principle does not lose its potency?Thielicke's ideas about moral guilt are both deeply existential and deeply theological. For Thielicke, the guilt that results from moral dilemmas is debilitating to the point that it leaves the Christian moral agent with very few viable options. Indeed, he does not see the task of evangelical theological ethics as providing easy answers or solutions to ethical problems.6 Roman Catholic casuistry and its legalistic and naturalistic theology falls prey to this temptation. He uses the term "borderline situations" (Grenzsituation) to depict what he calls "abnormal cases," ones that involve "transitions or complications" (Thielicke 1966, 578).7 The prime example of such a situation for Christians, according to Thielicke, is when they must use the methods of their evil opponent, as in the case of the duty to fight oppressive tyrannical dictatorships. Thus the individual Christian, especially if he holds political responsibility, is "ineluctably forced into a situation in which he must act within a framework of injustice" (585). What such situations teach Christians is that the world is fallen: "man has perverted his world, and no man is exempt from sharing responsibility for this human character of his world, this demonic humanizing of the world. No man is merely the object of a conflict situation. We are all part of the human subject that helped to bring it about" (597). Thus what is communal about this guilt for Thielicke is that the difficult moral conflict serves to remind Christians of their ongoing guilt as children of Adam. The borderline situation has its "origin in a communal guilt which already stands behind our situation and which we for our part ever increase and intensify…. We are both channels and perpetrators of cosmic guilt" (602).Borderline questions, according to Thielicke, "preclude the possibility of any final answers." He writes, "The questions must remain open" (1970, 147). The impossibility of any final answers to difficult moral dilemmas is firmly grounded in certain theological presuppositions, such as human sinfulness. Thielicke understands the human condition of sin as a usurpation of man's limits—a going beyond the limits to which humans are destined. Put differently, it is that man "has placed himself in sinful contradiction to the destiny for which he was created" (154). In essence, human creativity—the ability to transform nature into culture—is always tainted by humanity's inability to accept its destiny as God's creatures. Humans are always pressing the boundaries of their creatureliness. He contrasts the Christian view that identifies suffering with human guilt and responsibility to secular ideas that attribute life's tragedy to the structures of the world. He writes, "In myth … this world which is no longer whole tends to be regarded as something given, an intact structure in which guilt and fate are inseparably interwoven. The Bible, on the contrary, looks instead at man. It sees not the structure, but this personal representative of our disjointed world" (156).Human sinfulness is not manifested in particular actions. Rather it is the very structure of human existence that is the root of human guilt. In essence, for Thielicke, there is no possible choice that a human can make in the face of any moral decision that would relieve her of this existential guilt: "It is a matter of being, not action" (164). Yet there are certain types of situations in which human decisions and human actions can bring about greater guilt. Indeed it is the experience of guilt that is a measure of the person's moral health and well-being. Like a wound that cannot be allowed to heal, the guilt one feels when making difficult moral decisions such as allocating scarce medical resources is difficult. In contrast to the utilitarian who is able to make a decision with clear-cut objective criteria, the moral person must suffer the anguish of the "impossibility of the task." Her suffering is felt in "pangs of conscience" that are "a kind of gauze placed in the wound to prevent its healing in the wrong way." Continuing with the metaphor, he insists that while the wound must not be closed, it must not be allowed to infect the moral actor: "The pus of the insoluble dilemma must have some way of escaping. Otherwise, the very humanity of the physician himself becomes infected; he succumbs to the illusion of the easy solution" (173). Only by keeping the wound open does Thielicke believe that humans can arrive at an awareness of the very essence of what it is to be human.The most obvious contrast between Thielicke and Childress in the Soundings article is that Childress's view of human guilt is not explicitly connected to theological and existential ideas about the ongoing guilt of humans before God. Thielicke's view of cosmic guilt undermines his confidence that any method of deciding how to allocate scarce lifesaving devices can ever really be justifiable. He invokes casting lots, but unlike Childress, his endorsement of it is lukewarm at best. He sees it as an unsatisfactory option but perhaps the best one humans have available to them in such a situation.There are two points from the Soundings article that are relevant to my attempt to rethink the concept of moral traces. First, while Childress's view about guilt in "borderline situations" is not explicitly developed in the article, his engagement with Thielicke is illuminating because I believe it foreshadows his later emphasis on moral traces. Thielicke's insistence that the "wound" should not infect the actor supports my contention that moral traces ought to do more than simply affect the individual; they must incur some sense of obligation to others. Second, Childress bases his strong support of random selection on the belief that it is the best option for maintaining human dignity, equality, and trust. All three of these values are, in his view, important for building and maintaining relationships. Childress is explicit about this in several places in the article. Quoting Paul Ramsey, he describes equality of opportunity "as the ethical substance of the relations of those individuals to one another"(Childress 1970, 348). In another passage, he describes trust as "an attitude of expectation about another," namely, the expectation that one will be treated with respect (349).When we turn to Childress's 1978 article on just war in Theological Studies, we begin to see the full development of the concept of moral traces. In this more extended discussion, he situates them within "the logic of prima-facie duties." Relying on the moral philosopher W. D. Ross, he argues that prima facie obligations are more binding than relative principles that function like rules of thumb, and less binding than absolute principles that can never be overridden. Thus, a prima facie obligation is "intrinsically binding, but it does not necessarily determine one's actual obligation" (1978, 430). A central component of the logic of these conflicting obligations is that "an overridden or outweighed prima-facie obligation continues to function in the situation and the course of action one adopts" (431; emphasis mine). Childress explicitly uses the phrases "moral traces" and "residual effects" in this article to describe how the outweighed obligation "continues to function."He also turns to A. C. Ewing, who specifies more clearly how the overridden obligation continues to have a hold on the moral agent. For Ewing this hold results in a "mental attitude" that evokes regret, but even more important, that ought to affect the agent's future actions. Ewing writes, "My omission to fulfill my prima facie duty to him in this case will increase the force of any prima facie obligations I may have to him as regards future actions. And even if it did not affect overt action, the existence of a prima facie obligation not to do it should always affect our mental attitude towards an action." Ewing describes the mental attitude as "a positive thing even if not translated into action" and writes further that "a good man will at least regret the violation of prima facie duties" (1959, 110). In a footnote, Childress comments that for W. D. Ross, the appropriate response to an overridden obligation is not shame or repentance but rather compunction.Childress's views about the intensity of this mental attitude after a moral conflict are not fully developed in this discussion. Yet he manages to introduce a broad array of terms to describe it: residual effects, regret, shame, repentance, compunction. He seems to favor the terms—traces and residue—that suggest a less intense effect on the moral agent. Elsewhere in the article, he claims more directly that guilt is not the appropriate emotional attitude in such cases. He supports, without fully developing, a notion of "creative regret" that he borrows from Albert R. Di Ianni (Childress 1978, 433). However, in discussing the jus ad bellum criterion of "right intention" as the maintenance of proper motives, he states "an attitude of regret, if not remorse, is appropriate when a prima-facie obligation is overridden" (438). Such a clear statement equating moral traces with regret is not typical of his discussions in later work, such as Principles of Bioethics (PBE).Nevertheless, in his view, overriding a principle does lead to specific obligations. These are most explicit in his discussion of the jus in bello criteria—the criteria that govern how to conduct war. His primary point is that even though a just war requires one to overrule the prima facie obligation not to injure or kill another, the hold that the obligation has on the moral agent is not "overruled." In other words, the agent still must discharge some obligations to the other—and these obligations require that (1) the immediate object of war is not to kill or even injure, (2) one ought not directly target noncombatants, (3) one cannot impose "unnecessary suffering," and (4) any effect (even if only indirect) of war on civilians "must be justified by the principle of proportion" (441). By connecting moral traces to the jus in bello criteria, Childress reinforces a notion that these traces are more than just an internal wound or disposition, and instead constitute an attitude that necessarily entails an obligation to minimize the harms caused by overriding a prima facie duty.When we turn our attention to Childress's later work, especially in PBE, we see that moral traces play a significant role in two ways: to remind the agent that prima facie duties are not neutral values and to highlight the centrality of conscience and integrity as virtues in the practice of medicine. The account of the logic of prima facie duties in PBE follows quite closely the account presented in the earlier just-war article. For example, Childress and his coauthor, Tom Beauchamp, argue that when overriding a prima facie obligation, there will always be traces of "regret and a sense of moral residue." They write, "Moral residue results because an overridden prima facie obligation does not simply go away when overridden" (Beauchamp and Childress 2009, 19). While overlapping in some ways with their discussion of conscience, the two concepts remain distinct. Childress describes conscience as "an internal sanction that comes into play through critical reflection." While this sanction may have different forms, he notes that it "often appears as a bad conscience—in the form of feelings of remorse, guilt, shame, disunity, or disharmony—as the individual recognizes his or her acts as wrong" (44). The sanction of a bad conscience is different from the feeling of moral traces, because with the former, the agent feels that the act she performed is wrong. Moral traces, by contrast, imply that one has "residual obligations" or that one needs to at least acknowledge internally that an important obligation or value has been sacrificed, but not that the act itself is wrong. Nevertheless, moral traces share with the conscience the ability to help repair any disunity or disharmony that the agent may have experienced in the context of the difficult dilemma.One final example of the role of moral traces in Childress's work comes from his writings on the moral foundations of public health. Along with several colleagues, he has suggested that public health officials must satisfy five justificatory conditions when choosing to override individual liberty or justice. These are effectiveness, proportionality, necessity, least infringement, and public justification. It is the last of these that I think illustrates most clearly the connection between moral traces and obligations. In particular, the public health setting provides an example of institutional obligations that result from acknowledging that an important value has been overridden. The responsibility that public officials have in this regard is "to explain and justify that infringement, whenever possible, to the relevant parties, including those affected by the infringement." They must offer moral reasons because they are required to "treat citizens as equals" (Childress et al. 2002, 173). This activity of accountability to the public is, in Childress's words, "indispensable for engendering and sustaining public trust, as well as for expressing justice." It involves actively seeking ways to engage the public with the decisions being made on its behalf. This engagement involves seeking out the public's input, maintaining transparency about the process, and providing relevant information to the public. Although Childress and his coauthors do not use the language of moral traces in this discussion of public justification, their appeal to the obligations that public authorities have when they have infringed upon or overridden important moral values is a by-product of the traces. Childress's emphasis on ongoing obligations illustrates his belief that difficult moral decisions do not come to an abrupt end; they do not disappear. Rather, responsible moral agents ought to continue to act and feel in ways that acknowledge the ongoing implications of these decisions.What can we conclude about Childress's view of moral traces from this quick summary of his work? First, it seems clear that he does not see moral traces as identical to moral regret. Individuals can experience moral traces while being sure that they made the right decision in difficult moral situation. In other words, they are not wishing that they had done something else.8 Rather, they are taking the implications of what they did seriously. Second, his view of moral traces as incurring ongoing obligations supports an account of agency that is relational. This conclusion runs counter to prevailing critiques of Childress's "principlism" that depict it as grounded in a conception of the agent as an isolated, atomistic individual.Accounts of personhood as relational have become fairly commonplace in normative ethical discussions, especially ones that are informed by feminist, virtue, narrative, or communitarian visions. The "relational self" is usually posited over against the individualistic moral agent believed to be prevalent in certain liberal philosophical approaches. This individualistic vision of autonomy is also commonly associated with bioethics discourse, especially with Childress's approach.9 Critics of autonomy worry about the tendency to see the self as independent and separate from the discursive contexts that shape our commitments and values. They think a more accurate description of moral agency is one of responsiveness to the particularities of situations and to the network of dependencies that enable individuals to flourish. While the emphasis on particularity and dependency has been appealing to many feminist theorists, some have rejected a wholesale abandonment of autonomy as potentially antithetical to feminist political goals. They are skeptical of views that mistakenly stereotype individual autonomy as fundamentally individualistic and rationalistic. Thus they want to salvage autonomy because of the central role they believe it plays in feminist analyses of oppression, subjection, and agency. The model of relational autonomy has emerged as a useful hybrid that takes the concerns raised by critics of autonomy seriously without abandoning the important function of respect for the dignity of the individual.10The principle of autonomy is clearly central to Childress's ethics. Even in the Soundings article, we can see that he supports random selection for the allocation of scarce medical resources because it preserves respect for dignity and autonomy. Yet it is important to note that for Childress this respect for autonomy does not preclude attention to relationships. Indeed, it is intimately tied to the attitudes of trust necessary for society to function. Trust provides us with one example of a deeply relational concept that is intimately tied to respect for autonomy, insofar as it reflects our ultimate respect for the other's dignity and humanity. Childress's emphasis on moral traces and the obligations they produce also supports a concept of autonomy that is attentive to human relationships. While Childress avoids pressing moral traces and regret into the stronger realms of remorse or guilt, his emphasis on residual obligations in the contexts of war, bioethics, and public health suggests that the effects of moral traces extend beyond individual conscience. They require the moral agent to attend to the impact of her act on human relationships, both private and public. This suggests that for Childress, no moral decision exists in an isolated vacuum. We cannot thus speak of individual autonomy apart from the broader social contexts that all humans inhabit. As Courtney Campbell reminds us, certain elements of Childress's theology—namely, his claims about humans created in God's image—provide the basis for a view of autonomy that goes against certain secular notions of autonomy that privilege individualism and self-determination. Childress's theologically informed view of autonomy, according to Campbell, "must be qualified by considerations of dependence, sociality, and finitude" (Campbell 1989).Moral traces result when one voluntarily makes a choice to act in a certain way, but recognizes that in one's doing so, an important moral principle or value is threatened or even sacrificed. But what about cases in which the choice to act is not completely voluntary, when the agent is constrained by institutional pressures? These cases are captured by the terms moral distress and moral residue—terms that have come to be associated primarily with nursing ethics. The discussion of these terms is not always very precise in the literature, where we often see the terms conflated. It is useful, however, to get a sense of how these concepts work and to ask whether they offer any useful insights for thinking about the relational component of moral traces.The appeal to the language of moral distress and moral residue in nursing ethics refers to a much more intense sentiment than Childress's appeal to moral traces. Indeed, at times it sounds like a radically different phenomenon—something that results from forced violations of moral values, rather than from genuinely dilemmatic situations. In that sense, it is more like situations that involve violations of conscience and integrity. Recall that in PBE, Beauchamp and Childress distinguish moral traces from conscience. Nevertheless, discussions of moral distress can show us how internal reflections about our moral choices can and should have an effect on our obligations to others. More particularly, they draw attention to the implications of moral traces on institutional structures and procedures.Jameton's pioneering article on the issue of moral distress in nursing makes an important distinction between moral dilemmas (which Childress believes gives rise to moral traces) and moral distress. Moral dilemmas occur when "it is clear to the nurse that different and important values conflict, but no choice presents itself that preserves both" (Jameton 1993, 542). In contrast, distress is what occurs when a moral agent is unable to act on a judgment as a result of institutional or professional constraints. For Jameton, moral dilemmas present interesting material for students of philosophy to ponder, but in reality, they are rare and, in his words, "are bad news and to be avoided" (543). By dismissing moral dilemmas as rare occurrences, Jameton pays little attention to the experiences of moral regret or guilt. He worries, however, that nurses often conflate or confuse dilemmas (in the philosophical sense) with the experience of moral distress. In other words, when asked to describe their experiences, nurses often characterize the distress they feel at not being able to act on their judgments as dilemmatic. Although he acknowledges that distress can and often does give rise to "second-order" moral dilemmas, it is a mistake to view situations when one's choices are constrained institutionally as dilemmatic. To do so leads nurses to unnecessarily blame themselves for situations over which they have little control. I think Jameton's point is pertinent because I take him to be saying that when nurses view their actions as resulting from genuine dilemmas instead of from unjust institutional structures, they will experience the wrong kind of guilt. What really matters for nurses is that institutions treat them justly by allowing them opportunities to participate fully in the decision-making process. Jameton is worried about the conflation of dilemmatic situations and situations of moral distress because of its implications for moral responsibility. The importance of the category of "moral distress" is that it draws attention to how nurses are often forced to act in ways that violate their deeply held beliefs and commitments. This violation leads to a significant moral crisis that can potentially paralyze the agent. In other words, unlike moral traces, moral distress does little for relationship and community building. Indeed, it leads to disintegration. The "distressed" nurse is isolated and finds herself alienated from her institutional and professional role. In the end, while the literature on moral distress often seems to be referring to something different from moral traces in the sense that Childress uses the term, it can offer us some useful insight about relationship/community building in the aftermath of difficult moral problems. In particular, it helps us to think about how moral traces in Childress's sense ought to lead to just social and institutional arrangements.Margaret Battin's recent contribution to public health ethics offers us more resources for thinking about moral traces and their relational features. She intends her work as an intervention in bioethics and public health ethics—one that attempts to undermine the notion of the self that underlies these approaches. Her approach is animated by several concerns. One has to do with a failure of bioethics to account for infectious disease as a defining feature of human experience. For Battin, this seemingly minor oversight overlooks something very important about our nature as human animals. She writes, "Infectiousness is an especially direct reminder of how misleading the paradigms of individualism can be" (Battin et al. 2009, 78). Battin's overarching goal, however, is to develop a more sensitive account of public health ethics. While she does not explicitly address the ideas of regret, remorse, or conscience, I believe her reminder about our biological reality as deeply interconnected creatures serves as a useful impetus for thinking about the implications of relational autonomy.Battin describes the self as a "way-station," and "embedded" self, a vision of subjectivity that resonates with many feminist critiques of autonomy.11 Battin's important insight is that to speak of persons as shaped and constituted by and through their webs of relations is to speak about something physical and biological. She visualizes, rather than a romantic vision of relationality as constituted merely by friendship and familial relations, the individual as a "launching pad and breeding ground for trillions of organisms that move from one human being to another, either directly or by way of intermediate vectors" (462). This biological view expands the feminist account of relational autonomy. She writes, "Attention to social locatedness is not enough. Physical locatedness … is critical as well" (78).While clinical medicine has tended to see the patient primarily as a victim, public health has seen the patient primarily as a vector. Battin urges public health and bioethics to view patients as both simultaneously, "an account in which the patient can be seen as both victim and vector at the same time, a person simultaneously occupying both morally relevant roles" (87). Another way to put this is that we need to think of ourselves not only in terms of the threats to us but also in terms of the threats we potentially pose to others. This, according to Battin, draws a more nuanced and complex picture of moral agency. In particular it complicates notions of responsibility and blame that posit that we can always know who is to blame and for what. The biological view of ourselves as victims and vectors of infectious disease acknowledges that we cannot always know with certainty who is to blame (who harms and who is harmed).This view of the self provides an interesting grounding to the notion of moral traces as a relational concept. Agents in a dilemmatic situation are never fully relieved of the traces of guilt or sorrow for what they have done, and that is a good thing. It serves as a reminder of our shared vulnerability and woundedness as human subjects. In other words, our actions have effects and the virtuous agent is sensitive to these effects. In the image of Battin's way-station self we see how we are all biologically connected in pathways of disease. In a similar way moral traces remind us of our roles as both subjects and objects.We can see the implications of Battin's metaphysical view in her treatment of the ethics of distribution of scarce medical resources in cases of pandemic emergencies. She concurs with the pandemic triage plans put forth by Canada, Tennessee, and Utah that all base their allocation decisions on "medical criteria of survivability and need" (397). However, she notes that the patient as victim and vector (PVV) perspective draws our attention to two additional points. First, these plans fail to give an adequate account of what kind of care those who are "deprioritized" receive, and second, existing injustices in health care are exacerbated by these allocation criteria. Consequently, Battin argues that the plans must be clear about the obligation they have to care for those who will not be first in the queue to receive care in such an emergency. The issue of injustice only makes clear that we have an obligation to attend to health care inequities before such emergency situations strike. These conclusions illustrate the importance of the residual obligations incurred in situations of moral conflict. Like Childress's views about the necessity of the jus in bello criteria, and about the importance of public justifications in public health, Battin affirms that overriding a principle leaves traces that are not only wounding to the moral agent but also damaging to the relationships of trust that enable communities to exist and flourish.Without a strong sense of moral traces or even moral regret, we are left with a view of an agent who is not fully accountable to others—who can override important moral norms without having to incur any costs. Moral traces acknowledge the vulnerability and limits of our humanity. Yet it would be a mistake to stop there by allowing such an acknowledgment to turn us inward by focusing exclusively on whether our integrity has been damaged. Moral traces ought to do more than just make us feel bad. They are the impetus for broadcasting our accountability to others by offering reasons for our actions. In the case of the allocation of scarce medical resources, that accountability is necessary for extending and maintaining trust between health care providers and patients. Childress argues that randomness and chance are "most in accord with this relationship of trust" (1970, 349). Decisions about who should receive lifesaving treatments based on social worth are not attentive to the long-term effects of our actions on the fundamental relationships that form the basis of our society.

papers.title: “Self-Realisation Leads to the God Realisation”
papers.abstract: Every person’s life is like Kurukshetra; their good qualities are like friends, and their bad qualities are like enemies. Life itself is like a battlefield where we have to make the right decisions to achieve our goals. Seldom does the mind become confused regarding right and wrong, and it wanders; in the meanwhile, we make the wrong decision. As a result, there is a struggle between good and dreadful, false and truth, and true and evil. The term “Dharmakshetra” refers to this. When one is surrounded by unfavourable gesture impressions of the outside world or one’s own physical possessions, the mind is triggered to defend the originality of the intrinsic self, which prevents one from making the optimal decisions. When the mind is surrounded with detrimental gesture impressions of the environment or one’s own belongings, it triggers a lot to sustain the originality of the intrinsic self, which prevents one from making the optimal decisions. Our current field, whether it be tangible or incorporates different facets of life, including the job, family, business, or the social, political, economic, and moral domains in which we are pursuing our vocations, is becoming more and more like “Kurukshetra.” We all need the knowledge that Krishna imparted to Arjuna on the battlefield upon the soul and its features as well as God and his attributes, just as Arjuna required Lord Krishna’s advice in the Gita. Therefore, in order to maintain a peaceful, enjoyable existence free from hardships and ill luck, it is essential to do yoga and to be aware of both God and thyself. We compare the many viewpoints of the Gita via that of Brahma Kumari, who has deep ideas and whose opinions are very identical, in an effort to make the readers feel more secure and conscious of both God and oneself.Similar to this, there are several parallels between the soul, the absolute soul, and yoga, including the Bhagavad-Gita’s philosophical lines and spiritual content. papers.title: A new definition of noise: noise is unwanted and/or harmful sound. Noise is the new ‘secondhand smoke’.
papers.abstract: The words sound and noise are used interchangeably in acoustics, electronics, and physics, but have different connotations when applied to listeners. Sound is defined as vibrations that travel through air or another medium that can be heard when they reach a person's or animal's ears. Noise is defined as unwanted sound. In engineering, noise has the additional connotation of signals varying over time without meaning, whereas sound connotes meaningful signals. Unfortunately, the phrase unwanted sound implies that noise is merely a nuisance, ignoring what is now known about the harmful effects of noise on people and animals. It also implies a value judgment about noise, with a subjective component to the judgment of the listener complaining about noise. Often, there is an additional implication that those who complain about noise are neurotic, weak, self-centered, or have some other psychological or psychiatric problem that for them magnifies the impact of "harmless" sounds that don't bother others. This latter implication is incorrect. Desired sounds can cause auditory damage, and unwanted sound is harmful. Evidence-based noise levels affecting human heath and function are well known. That is why I propose a new definition of noise: Noise is unwanted and/or harmful sound.

papers.title: Separation and reunification in disasters: The importance of understanding the psychosocial consequences
papers.abstract: Disasters, often being sudden-onset and destructive events, produce unpredictable consequences that frequently lead to the separation of family members. People mention that separation from family members is one of the most stressful aspects of such events. Hazards may restrict physical access to an area, both during the threat period and afterwards due to the loss of transport infrastructure (e.g., roads), and communications may be disrupted directly or indirectly through loss of power. As a result of this disruption to people's ability to communicate with each other, many emergency management systems recognize the importance of reuniting families separated by disaster, and therefore provide a means for people to reunite (e.g., Safe and Well operated by the American Red Cross). 2 The term "reunification" is commonly used in the emergency sector. In this chapter, it refers to the point when someone becomes aware of their family member's status and whereabouts (e.g., through phone contact, word of mouth, Internet, face-to-face, or through the Red Cross); it does not necessarily involve being brought together in the same physical location. Despite the rationale for reunification services being supportive for people's wellbeing, there is little empirical evidence relating to the short-and longer-term psychosocial impact of separation from family members during and immediately after a disaster event.

papers.title: Words and Deeds
papers.abstract: Abstract For the Kuranko, social skills and social intelligence were the measure of a person's moral worth. We, however, are accustomed to according greater value to purely subjective qualities. Whenever the author tried to ascertain what a person thought or felt about a particular event, or another person, villagers would typically respond by declaring, "I am not inside them" (n'de sa bu ro), or "I do not know what is inside" (n'de ma konto lon), thereby reminding us that what matters is how a person behaves in relation to others, irrespective of what is in his heart or on his mind. As for intelligence, this was not defined by the esoteric knowledge you possessed any more than wealth was defined by the money you had in the bank or the amount of rice in your granary. Rather, it was expressed in the adroitness with which you engaged with others – the way you greeted or cooperated with them, the way you performed your duties and met your obligations. This ethos extended to emotionality. Unless one's personal feelings had some social value, they should not be publicly expressed.

papers.title: More than Five : 共感覚が浮き彫りにする五感以外の感覚
papers.abstract: It is commonly said that we human beings have five senses - touch, taste, smell, vision, and hearing. This classification of senses depends on the fact that a human being has five kinds of sense organ - skin, tongue, nose, eyes, and ears. However, synesthesia in language indicates that we have additional senses. This study examines synesthetic metaphors in Japanese. Synesthetic metaphors are expressions in which the words or phrases proper to one sense describe the experiences of another sense. When we describe our experiences of one of the five senses, we can use three types of expressions. Words proper to that sense, explanatory expressions such as “nakitakunaru-yohna iro”（＝a color which makes me cry), and synesthetic metaphors (that is, words which originally relate to another sense). Some words like “hukai” (＝deep), “hageshii” (＝violent), or “sabishii” (＝lonely) describe the experiences of some of the five senses, like “hukai oto” (＝deep sound), “hageshii iro” (＝violent color), and “sabishii iro” (＝lonely color). But they do not originally relate to any of those senses, and are not explanatory either. These expressions are synesthetic metaphors and the adjectives must be words of some senses other than the five. The existence of these synesthetic metaphors proves that we have three more senses other than the five, at least in Japanese, - “dimension,” “movement,” and “mood.”

papers.title: Neurobiological Foundations of Stress
papers.abstract: Modern understanding of stress stems from classic work in the 1930s by Hans Selye, who developed the notion of the general adaptation syndrome (Selye, 1936). Selye posited that the body shows a common, integrated set of responses in an attempt to adapt to many different kinds of stress. Until his work, many scientists viewed different kinds of stress as having different effects on the body; for example, the effect of exposure to severe cold was thought to be very different from the effect of blood loss. Indeed, each particular type of stressor does have unique effects. However, Selye showed that different severe stressors also have common features. He identified three stages. First is the shock (or alarm) phase, involving decreased blood pressure, body temperature, and muscle tone (the reader has no doubt experienced at least some degree of shock following a minor or not so minor injury, particularly if blood loss occurred). Selye termed the second phase of the adaptation response the stage of resistance, when the body fights back. If the stress is severe and continues for a long period, the body defenses break down and the third stage, exhaustion, ensues. Among other things, this stage includes a marked impairment of the immune system.

papers.title: 여가의 본질적 의미에 관한 철학적 탐구
papers.abstract: In general. an understanding of leisure should take account of the dimensions of time, activity and experience. But, leisure time is usually considered as residual time that individuals can use for their relaxation, diversion, social interaction or personal developments, free from work and other duties. However, it is not simply free time, as many unemployed people argue that such enforced time free from work does not provide them with true leisure. When we consider leisure as activity, we often list hobbies or pastimes that we choose to be involved in because we value and enjoy them. Leisure may offer means of diversion separate from non-leisure activities such as work, or an opportunity for self expression or self-development. To that degree, leisure is not a purposeless activity. It is said that leisure is a state of mind or mental condition in which we find freedom in a freely chosen activity that we undertake for its own intrinsic reasons. In other words, leisure is in the mind of the participant, and it is activity that is chosen primarily for its own sake. However, in contemporary concept, it is clear that leisure includes some ideologies in which there are educational and social purposes intentioned to control people. In this sense, the most important meaning of leisure is that leisure is not just free time, rather it is closer to social welfare aspect in contemporary society. Leisure does not exist any more as traditional concept.

papers.title: Psychology of Cool: Meaning and Marketing
papers.abstract: The word ‘cool’ has entered in the currency of language, especially that of young people. The term enjoys a distinct and well defined meaning in dictionary. In denotative sense it is related to the degree of temperature of a liquid or object or a body. It implies a state when something is ‘neither warm nor very cold or is moderately cold’ 2. Often ‘cool’ is also used in contexts other than relating to temperature, when it signifies character of a person, place or brand. Anything that is considered to be cool enjoys attraction and hence enjoys customer following. However, a perception of ‘un-cool’ has a value robbing effect from a product, place or phenomenon. If being cool can possibly give competitive edge in terms of customer desirability and following, it assumes significance from marketing perspective.

papers.title: Anger and fear
papers.abstract: The author proposes that fear and anger are innate defensive mechanisms mobilized by preceived threats to the individual. Both mechanisms are accompanied by anxiety and an urge to escape or attack. The individual's lifestyle, which is the result of interaction between his innate qualities and life experiences, determines whether he will attempt to deal with threats, his fear and/or anger, and the resulting anxiety in an objective or pathological manner. This formulation underscores the need to learn methods of coping with anger and fear from early childhood, so that they do not develop into pathological behavior patterns.

papers.title: HEALING HEART CONTACT / ISCJELJUJUĆI KONTAKT SRCA
papers.abstract: In Gestalt therapy, good psychological health implies good contact with oneself and with others. Contact, with awareness and experiment, is one of the basic terms in gestalt therapy. It is defined as a relationship between oneself and the other (the environment or internal aspects such as alienated parts of self, blocked emotions, thoughts, memories, or anything that is not integrated into a person, and is not perceived as “I” but as “the other”). To be able to contact others and their hearts, we must first be aware of our heart – its condition, needs, and desires. We usually become aware of our heart when some negative emotion arises or when its rhythm changes, which is characteristic of the broken heart syndrome. This condition manifests with abnormal chest pain and/or lack of air, preceded by strong emotional stress that is most often associated with anxiety and/or panic attack. The paper describes the process of development of the broken heart syndrome, as well as possibilities of treatment. Finally, we can conclude that the broken heart syndrome is a paradox: it is an expression of vitality but also a defense against vitality; the manifestation is a “problem” but also a means of solving it. The primary purpose of suffering and negative experiences is healing: suffering can be a tool that  helps us become complete.  True healing always implies the spread of the heart and the expansion of consciousness. Ultimately, every successful healing of the broken heart will result in an emotional-spiritual growth and development.

papers.title: Egosystem and EcosystemMotivational Perspectives on Caregiving
papers.abstract: In this essay, we consider the motivations people have for caregiving, and the consequences of these motivations for the self and others. We argue that there are at least two fundamentally different views, or motivational perspectives, that people can have about caregiving. Caregiving in the egosystem is viewed as a means for people to satisfy their own needs and desires; although their behavior may appear selfless or self-sacrificing, they provide care because of what they will obtain, or what it means about them. In contrast, caregiving in the ecosystem results from genuine concern for the well-being of others; although such caregiving often has benefits for the self, those benefits are not the primary reasons why people provide care. These two motivational perspectives on caregiving have paradoxical effects; we describe evidence that caregiving in the egosystem, which aims to obtain benefits for the self, actually undermines the support the caregiver receives from others, undermines relationship quality, decreases the caregiver’s self-esteem and mental health, and even decreases the regard the care recipient has for the caregiver. Because caregivers often are unaware of these paradoxical effects, when they feel that their needs are not being met, they can persist with giving care in the egosystem, creating just the opposite of what they really want. In contrast, caregiving in the ecosystem, actually does benefit the self, in the form of increased support received from others, increased self-esteem and mental health in the caregiver, and increased regard the recipient has for the caregiver.

papers.title: Entertainment and the Nostalgia of Values
papers.abstract: Abstract Whether we talk of Stanislavski’s theatre of living, or Meyerhold’s biomechanics (through which the eccentric actor can respond to the most unexpected emotional or physical requests), or Brecht’s theatre of alienation of representation, or psychological theatre, which pays attention to the character’s conduct, inspired by some of the discoveries of American behaviourists, in all these instances there is a certain common essential point, which, of course, is directly reached through nothing other than the false or truthful image of the contemporary man on the living stage. I believe that great achievements in acting are beyond the split between emotion and idea, or the illusory antagonism of conscious and unconscious, intelligence and sensitivity.

papers.title: The Attention
papers.abstract: In perception, objects come to the attention. Accordingly, one might come to believe that ‘The Attention’ names the capacity to harbour events of the specific idiosyncratic type, noticing. In fact it signifies an experiential mental space to which objects can come in perception and, which can contain experiences. After all, many mental phenomena other than perception require awareness if they are to so much as exist, e.g. emotion and thought, thanks to being experiences. That experiential space is of limited extent, for at any moment the mind can experience so much and no more. Indeed, the space is no more than the existence of such a limit, and has no autonomous existence other than the fact of that limit, and it is a dangerous illusion to hypostatize the limit as a real space, leading one to misunderstand what it is to experience an experience. Then there is reason for supposing that the experiences of the moment constitute a system. This circle or centre of awareness is the Attention. And it is to this Attention that perceived existents come—as object. This happens when a noticing or perceiving occurs.

papers.title: Major organ loss from post-mortem animal predation: Issues arising from emptied body cavities
papers.abstract: The feeding of animals on bodies after death - so-called post-mortem animal predation - may complicate autopsy interpretations when there has been removal of significant amounts of skin and tissues. An extreme situation which sometimes arises is the complete evisceration and/or consumption of all major cavity organs. Search of autopsy files at Forensic Science South Australia was undertaken for examples of this phenomenon. Although such a finding at autopsy may suggest the actions of larger animals such as dogs or sharks, it may also occur when groups of smaller animals, such as cats, act in concert. Complete loss of organs may also occur if significant insect activity accompanies decomposition. Empty body cavities may therefore result from of a wide variety of animal activities involving a range of species in quite different environments. A significant problem once organs have been removed or consumed is in identifying or excluding natural diseases or injuries that may have played a role in the lethal episode.

papers.title: 프라이버시 최적화 공간을 위한 신경건축
papers.abstract: The familiar idea we have about privacy is the separation from others eyes or concern. But, in 1970s Irwin Altman, social psychologist, defined privacy as process of interpersonal boundary regulation. He interpreted it as a dialectic process, which involves both a restriction of interaction and a seeking of interaction. An optimum state of privacy is reached when the desired privacy is equal to the achieved one. If achieved privacy is lower than desired privacy, there comes the sense of crowding. In case of contrary situation, we feel isolated. Desired privacy changes over time depending on situation and a person continue feedback loop until desired privacy is achieved. Under difficult condition, this process requires much energy expenditure. If the same status lasts, diverse physiological and psychological problem shall occur. Single-person household rapidly growing in recent years has a difficulty in the regulation of privacy. Because the environment surrounding their house does not have spatial layers which allow to choose different social interactions depending on their psychological conditions. The Sense of isolation coming from the failure of privacy regulation results in elevated stress, cardiovascular diseases, or lowered attention span. Therefore, the existence of public spaces such as parks is important. Because agreeable public spaces can give a place of mind to single residents, so they can expand their boundary of interaction with outer circumstances at residential areas. As well, oxytocin is a hormone to relieve the above-mentioned symptoms by either smoothing mind or forming fellowship. Studies on space to stimulate the release of oxytocin could be one of solutions to lessen the sense of isolation.

papers.title: Muscular tension: An explanation from a methodological behaviorism.
papers.abstract: Operant conditioning represents a unique data language that describes the lawfulness of behavior as derived from the cumulative record over time of consistent correlations between the universally observed or 'public' form or topography of behavior and its consequences. Operant conditioning procedures are based upon methodological principles, wherein reliable behavioral consistencies or 'laws' are derived using a data language that precisely maps to the universally agreed upon facts of behavior. As a form of methodological behaviorism (Pavlovian or classical conditioning is another example), the experimental methodology of operant conditioning directly measures and manipulates only publicly observable behavior. Grasping, walking, talking, etc. are operant behaviors because they are correlated with or are 'reinforced' by specific discrete outcomes. Because these behaviors uniformly engage a specific organelle of the body, namely the striated musculature, a common presumption is that operant conditioning primarily reflects the conditioning of these muscles. Of course, convulsions, startle reactions, etc. do involve the striated musculature and can be mediated by neurological rather than purely cognitive causes, but in general muscular activity is guided by its functionality as consciously perceived. It is commonly assumed that if striated muscles are activated, they are publically observed, and hence may be subsumed entire under an operant analysis. Yet only a fraction of striated muscular activity is observable publicly or privately. That is, the musculature may be activated yet not result in publicly observable responses, and neither may it be consciously or privately perceived by the individual. Ironically, the private activity of the musculature has long been made public through resolving instrumentalities (e.g., SCR, EMG) but rarely if ever has an operant analysis been employed to explain this behavior. Rather, tension has generally been construed to be an artifact of autonomic arousal that is elicited due to psycho-social 'demand'. This interpretation regards muscular tension as subsumed under different motivational principles that do not incorporate contingency, such as the reflexive or S-R responses entailed by a fight or flight response, stress reaction, etc. (Marmot & Wilkinson, 2006). In this case, inferred mediating processes take the place of observed correlations between behavior and environmental events. However, this conclusion may remain uncontested not because the relationship between tension and its governing contingencies is disproven, or because the relevant data are unobtainable, but because of a common misinterpretation of the semantics of 'demand'. The purpose of this article is to argue that the same data and data language used to establish the concept that tension is reflexive or is a respondent can be reinterpreted to unequivocally demonstrate that muscular tension is an instrumental or operant behavior. The Striated Musculature Although the activity of the striated musculature comprises the majority of behavior as we understand it, its psychophysiology is not widely known. Muscle are categorized into slow-twitch fibers and fast-twitch fibers (Squire, McConnell, & Zigmund, 2003). Slow-twitch (also called 1 muscle fibers) activate and deactivate slowly, but when activated they are also very slow to fatigue. Fast-twitch activate and deactivate rapidly and come in two types: 2A muscle fibers which fatigue at an intermediate rate, and 2B muscle fibers which fatigue rapidly. These three muscle fiber types (Types 1, 2A, and 2B) are contained in all muscles in varying amounts. Muscles that need to be activated much of the time (like postural muscles) have a greater number of Type 1 (slow) fibers. When a muscle begins to contract, primarily Type 1 are activated first, followed by Type 2A, then 2B. Type 1 are often monotonically activated because of psychosocial 'demand' that in general does not engage fast twitch fibers. …

papers.title: Secons steps to g
papers.abstract: We are now ready to formalise some of the ideas that have been illustrated in the previous two chapters in order to lay the groundwork for our later exposition of factor analysis. We begin with the most fundamental distinction of all. It is what distinguishes g from IQ, but it goes much wider. It concerns the difference between what, in technical language, are called manifest variables and latent variables. A variable is any quantity which varies from one member of a population to another – height and hair colour in the case of human populations, for example. A variable is manifest if it is possible to observe it and to record its value by counting or by using a measuring instrument like a ruler, clock or weighing machine. Thus, any variable whose magnitude can be observed and expressed in units of number, length, time or weight is a manifest variable. A great many variables which appear in social discourse are of this kind. The idea can be extended to cover anything calculated from a set of manifest variables, like an average, for example. In that sense IQ is a manifest variable because, as we have seen, it is something calculated from manifest test scores and is, therefore, itself, observable.

papers.title: Zoomorphism and anthropomorphism: fruitful fallacies?
papers.abstract: Abstract Zoo- and anthropomorphism may both be scientific heresies but both may serve as a basis for thought (and real) experiments designed to explore our ability to assess quality of life as perceived by another sentient animal. Sentience, a major contributor to evolutionary fitness in a complex environment, implies ‘feelings that matter’. Strength of motivation is a measure of how much they matter. Since humans and most domestic animals share the property of sentience, it follows that some aspects of feeling may be similar, and where we differ, the differences may be of degree rather than absolute. One of the assumed absolutes that I shall challenge is the concept that non-human animals live only in the present. I explore how domestic animals may experience the feelings of hunger, pain, fear and hope. Hunger is indisputably a primitive sensation. Pain and fear are primitive sensations with emotional overtones. The problem is to discover how they may affect quality of life. Acute pain and fear are positive signals for action to avoid harm. These actions and their consequences (‘how well did I cope?’) will be committed to memory and affect how an animal feels when they recur, or it fears they may recur. Hope (and its antithesis, despair) are considered by many philosophers (who do not own dogs) as emotions restricted to humans since only we can imagine the future. However, by application of zoomorphism we may classify hope with hunger as a primitive feeling of dissatisfaction with the status quo . Either may lead to action directed towards the goal of feeling better or encourage the belief that things will get better (food will arrive). Both are feelings of expectation for the future modulated in the light of past experience. With all these four emotions quality of life may be expressed in terms of how well the animal feels it can cope, both in the present and in the future. When it feels it cannot cope, then it will suffer.

papers.title: How voluntary control over information and body movements determines "what it's like" to have perceptual, bodily, emotional and mental experiences.
papers.abstract: Two very fundamental aspects of phenomenal experiences underlie the fact that they seem to have “something it’s like”. One aspect is the fact that experiences have a locus: they can seem “external” (perceptual), “internal” (interoceptive, bodily or emotional) or “mental”. A second fundamental aspect is the imposingness of experiences. They can seem “present” to us in different ways, sometimes seeming displayed before us with “spatio-temporal presence”.Both these aspects of “what it’s like” can be identified with the degree to which we can voluntarily control what we are doing when we engage in an experience. The external/internal/mental dimension is determined by how our voluntary bodily actions can influence the sensorimotor flow of information. The degree of imposingness of experiences and their “spatio-temporal presence” is determined by how our voluntary actions are impeded or assisted by innate, attention-grabbing mechanisms.By elucidating these two most fundamental aspects of “what it’s like”, and taken together with prior work on inter- and intra-modal differences in experiences, this article suggests a path towards a scientific theory of the “hard problem” of phenomenal consciousness, explaining why experiences feel like something rather than feeling like nothing.

papers.title: Looks: Subjectivity as commodity
papers.abstract: abstract Looking at, seeing, being looked at or being seen by certain people can afford libidinal excitation,1 1. Libidinal excitation is taken to mean the generation of energy associated with the libido, where libido means the psychical energy and desire derived from biological drives, specifically the sexual drive. but it also can be a source of psychical2 2. Psychical means that which has to do with the psyche which in turn refers to the human faculty for thought, perception as well as emotion. displeasure. Reading a series of events, texts, and images, this Article traces why and how we are excited or moved by the way we or others look. The Article argues that seeing or being seen by a sexual object3 3. Here, after Freud, the sexual object refers to the party at whom sexual feelings are directed. is an important source of libidinal pleasure around which a self and culture is built. Consequently, in late racialised capitalist culture, looking, being looked at, and generally looks (and inevitably subjectivities), cannot but become commodities, given that scopophilia4 4. In simple terms, the love of looking. lies behind the commodification of culture. The Article employs two cases as emblematic of commoditisation in late global capitalist culture: a research fragment about a father who disapproves of his dead son's dress choices; and second, the media-conveyed controversy around the athlete Caster Semenya. These are approached through constructionist and psychoanalytic registers, here taken as complementary approaches to a critical project on sexualities and gender. The Article demonstrates that the father seems to have looked upon his son as a man in the ‘wrong’ clothes, while Semenya is consciously or otherwise constructed in the media to be a woman in the “wrong” body. These constructions are grounded in the pleasure of looking or being looked at.

papers.title: Visual perception of surprising materials in dynamic scenes
papers.abstract: Many objects that we encounter have material qualities: spoons are hard, pillows are soft and jelly dessert is wobbly. Over a life time of experiences, strong associations between an object and its typical material properties may be formed, and these associations not only include how glossy, rough or pink an object is but also how it behaves under force: we expect knocked over vases to shatter, popped bike tires to deflate, and gooey grilled cheese to hang between two slices of bread when apart. Here we ask how such rich visual priors affect the visual perception of material qualities and present a particularly striking example of expectation violation. In a cue conflict design, we pair computer-rendered familiar objects with surprising material behaviors (a linen curtain shattering, a porcelain teacup wrinkling, etc.) and find that material qualities are not solely estimated from the object9s kinematics (i.e. its physical (atypical) motion while shattering, wrinkling, wobbling etc.); rather, material appearance is sometimes pulled towards the native motion, shape, and optical properties that are associated with this object. Our results, in addition to patterns we find in reaction time data, suggest that visual priors about materials can set up high-level expectations about complex future states of an object and show how these priors modulate material appearance. Understanding how high-level expectations are integrated with incoming sensory evidence is an essential step towards understanding how the human visual system accomplishes material perception.

papers.title: Circadian Sensation and Visual Perception
papers.abstract: The physiology of living beings presents oscillations that are known as biological rhythms. The most studied rhythm is called circadian (circa = circa, dies = day), because it varies with a period close to 24h. Most functions of the body have circadian variations, one can mention, for example, metabolism, body temperature, the activity of the nervous system, secretion of hormones such as melatonin and cortisol. Circadian rhythms were also found in human behavior, for example: in sensory activity, motor activity, reaction time, visual perception, auditory perception, time perception, attention, memory, arithmetic calculus, and executive functions. The present work reviews the visual path that participates in the synchronization of circadian rhythms, as well as the evidence that exists about the presence of circadian rhythms in the sensation and visual perception of the human being.

papers.title: Transformative Experiences
papers.abstract: Transformative experiences are experiential states that radically alter a person in some way, such as what the person can know or understand, their core values or preferences, their overall outlook on the world, and so on. Notable historical examples plausibly include the Apostle Paul's epiphany and sudden conversion to Christianity on the road to Damascus, St. Augustine's moral and spiritual transformation after the death of a close friend, and similar transformations by the Buddha and Muhammed. Such experiences have been argued to pose philosophical challenges for rational choice, as it appears unclear how one can make rational life‐choices about experiences one does not understand or which otherwise fundamentally transform oneself or one's values. Some theorists argue that rational choices involving transformative experiences are impossible. Others argue that transformative experiences instead pose a challenge to making choices that are both rational and authentic. Others still are unconvinced that transformative experiences pose any serious or unique problems to rational choice, contending that the problems they present are either exaggerated or reducible to problems unrelated to transformative experience. Finally, many solutions have been advanced for resolving the problems that transformative experiences are alleged to pose, including that transformative experiences can be chosen for their own sake, chosen on the basis of objective evidence such as statistics and testimony, chosen on the basis of imaginative comparison to relevantly similar past experiences, or, alternatively, be rationally grappled with by the development of internal mastery such as personal resilience or through moral behavior.
